utterances.transcript: Ow ow ow. Ow ow ow ow. Ow ow ow. Ow. Ow. Ow. Ow.

utterances.transcript: Hi. Uh, my friend here was taking down our Christmas lights, and and she fell off the balcony and may have broken her foot or or ankle or something.
My god. You still have your Christmas lights up?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Monica helps Rachel over to a vacant seat.)

utterances.transcript: Ow ow ow. Ow ow ow. Ow ow ow.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Monica starts on the form, while Rachel catches her breath and massages her ankle.)

utterances.transcript: Okay, ooh, alright. Name, address... Okay, in case of emergency, call?

Yeah.
Oh, that is so sweet. Oh gosh, love you. Insurance?

you don't have insurance?
utterances.transcript_with_note: (No longer touched) you don't have insurance?

Well there's not much we can do.
Um... unless, unless I use yours.

utterances.transcript: That's insurance fraud.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (Looking around to check that no-one's listening, then lowering her voice anyway) That's insurance fraud.

utterances.transcript_with_note: Well, alright, then, forget it. (Getting up to go) Might as well just go home. Ow ow ow ow!

utterances.transcript: Thank you. Thank you. I love you.

utterances.transcript: I had a dream last night where I was playing football with my kid.
That's nice.
No, no, with him. I'm on this field, and they, they hike me the baby... and I, I know I've gotta do something 'cause the Tampa Bay defence is comin' right at me.
utterances.transcript_with_note: No, no, with him. (He mimes holding the baby like a football.) I'm on this field, and they, they hike me the baby... and I, I know I've gotta do something 'cause the Tampa Bay defence is comin' right at me.

utterances.transcript: Tampa Bay's got a terrible team.
Right, but, it is just me and the baby, so I'm thinkin' they can take us. And so I uh, hah-hah, I just heave it down field.
What are you crazy? That's a baby!
He should take the sack?

Anyway, suddenly I'm down field, and I realise that I'm the one who's supposed to catch him, right? Only I know there is no way I'm gonna get there in time, so I am running, and running, and that, that is when I woke up. See I, I am so not ready to be a father.
Hey, you're gonna be fine. You're one of the most caring, most responsible men in North America. You're gonna make a great dad.
Yeah, Ross. You and the baby just need better blocking.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Feeling a little better, Ross fetches more coffee.)

I'm takin' Ursula tonight. It's her birthday.
Wo-wo-whoa. What about Phoebe's birthday?
When's that?
Tonight.
Oh, man. What're the odds of that happening?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Joey looks at his friends, thinks a bit more, then realises.)

Well, if she's my friend, hopefully she'll understand. I mean, wouldn't you guys?

utterances.transcript: I tell you one thing, I wouldn't mind having a piece of this sun-dried tomato business. Five years ago, if somebody had said to me, here's a tomato that looks like a prune, I'd say "get out of my office!"
Dad, before I was born, did you freak out at all?
I'm not freaking out, I'm just saying, if somebody had come to me with the idea andndash;
Dad, dad, dad, I'm talkin' about the whole uh, baby thing. Did you uh, ever get this sort of... panicky, "Oh my god I'm gonna be a father" kind of a thing?
No. Your mother really did the work. I was busy with the business. I wasn't around that much. Is that what this is about?
No, no, Dad, I was just wondering.
'Cause there's time to make up for that. We can do stuff together. You always wanted to go to that Colonial Williamsburg. How 'bout we do that?
Thanks, Dad, really, I ju... you know, I just, I just needed to know, um... when did you start to feel like a father?

Oh, well, I, I guess it musta been the day after you were born. We were in the hospital room, your mother was asleep, and they brought you in and gave you to me. You were this ugly little red thing, and all of a sudden you grabbed my finger with your whole fist. And you squeezed it, so tight. And that's when I knew.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ross is so moved by his father's charming story, that he stops eating.)

utterances.transcript: So you don't wanna go to Williamsburg?
No, we can go to Williamsburg.
Eat your fish.

plots: Ross talks with Ross ' father over lunch about Ross ' fears , which Jack talks Ross out of by recounting the first moment Jack had with Ross as a baby after birth , when Ross grabbed Jack 's finger with Ross ' tiny hand .

utterances.transcript: Rachel, the cute doctors are here.
Okay, coming!

utterances.transcript: Hi, come on in.
Hey.
Hi, Geoffrey.
Hi.
Ah here, we brought wine.
Look at this, it's from the cellars of Ernest and Tova Borgnine, so how could we resist?
Oh, that's great. Look at that.
So, Monica, how's the ankle?
It's uh...

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Rachel discreetly coughs to warn her.)

utterances.transcript: ..well, why don't you tell them? After all it, is your ankle.
You know what, it's feeling a lot better, thank you, um... Well, listen, why don't you two sit down and, and we'll get you some glasses... okay... STAT!
utterances.transcript_with_note: You know what, it's feeling a lot better, thank you, um... Well, listen, why don't you two sit down and, and we'll get you some glasses... okay... (They don't know what to do with their coats and Monica points to the living room) STAT!
(Rachel joins Monica who is in the kitchen area, opening the wine bottle. Rachel checks that the doctors aren't listening, then lowers her voice anyway.)

utterances.transcript: Okay, listen, I'm thinking, why don't we just tell them who we really are? I mean, it'll be fine, I really think it'll be fine.
It will not be fine. We'll get in trouble.
Oh, Monica! Would you stop being such a wuss?
A wuss? Excuse me for living in the real world, okay?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Back at the couch, Dr. Mitchell and Dr. Rosen have concerns of their own.)

utterances.transcript: So?
So... they sss-still seem normal.
That's because they are.
okay, but you have to admit that every time we go out... Women we meet at the hospital... It turns into...
utterances.transcript_with_note: (Nervously) okay, but you have to admit that every time we go out... Women we meet at the hospital... It turns into...

utterances.transcript: Willya relax? Look around. No pagan altars, no piles of bones in the corners, they're fine. Go like this.

(Meanwhile, back at the sink.)

utterances.transcript: I said we are not going to do it, okay? Sometimes you can be such a, a big baby.
I am not a baby! You know what? I swear to god, just because you get so uptight every time we...
utterances.transcript_with_note: (Resenting the truth) I am not a baby! You know what? I swear to god, just because you get so uptight every time we...

utterances.transcript: Sure, every time, you're such a princess...
You know what?
What?
You know what?
What!?
You know what?
What!!?
utterances.transcript_with_note: (getting angry) What!!?

utterances.transcript: Every day, you are becoming more and more like your mother.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Rachel brightly limps back across the apartment with glasses of wine for the cute doctors, leaving an open-mouthed Monica in her wake.)

utterances.transcript: Hello! Here we go!
This is a great place. How long have you lived here?
Thanks! I've been here about six years, and Rachel moved in a few months ago.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Monica) Thanks! I've been here about six years, and Rachel moved in a few months ago.

utterances.transcript: Yeah... ..see, I was supposed to get married, but, um, I left the guy at the altar.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) Yeah... (joining the others) ..see, I was supposed to get married, but, um, I left the guy at the altar.
(Rachel tries to hide her alarm, but she squirms in her chair.)

utterances.transcript: Really?
Yeah... Yeah, I know it's pretty selfish, but haha, hey, that's me. Why don't you try the hummus?
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) Yeah... Yeah, I know it's pretty selfish, but haha, hey, that's me. (Indicating a dish on the table) Why don't you try the hummus?

utterances.transcript: So, Monica, what do you do?
Aahh, I'm a... chef at a restaurant uptown.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Monica) Aahh, I'm a... chef at a restaurant uptown.

utterances.transcript: Good for you.
Yeah it is, mostly because I get to boss people around, which I just love to do.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Monica) Yeah it is, mostly because I get to boss people around, which I just love to do.

utterances.transcript: This hummus is great.
God bless the chickpea.
Oh, god, I am so spoiled... That's it!
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) (Suddenly laughing) Oh, god, I am so spoiled... That's it!
(The doctors don't know what to make of all this.)

utterances.transcript: And by the way, have I mentioned that back in high school, I was a cow?
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Monica) And by the way, have I mentioned that back in high school, I was a cow?

utterances.transcript: I used to wet my bed.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) I used to wet my bed.

utterances.transcript: I use my breasts to get other people's attention.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Monica) I use my breasts to get other people's attention.

utterances.transcript: We both do that!
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) (Revealing her anger to point at her best friend) We both do that!

(Rachel lets her anger show too. Hideously embarrassed, the doctors drain their glasses in the vicious pause which follows. The telephone rings, but the girls just glower at each other, silently daring the other to move first. Finally both guys jump up, and Michael wins.)

utterances.transcript: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Err yeh, aayah, yeh, just one second... ..ah, Rachel, it's your dad.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (on the phone) Monica and Rachel's apartment. Err yeh, aayah, yeh, just one second... (handing it to Monica) ..ah, Rachel, it's your dad.

utterances.transcript: Hi, Dad. No, no, it's me. li-listen, Dad, I can't talk right now, um, but there's something, um... there's something that I've been meaning to tell you...
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) Hi, Dad. No, no, it's me. (Getting up to move further away from Rachel) li-listen, Dad, I can't talk right now, um, but there's something, um... there's something that I've been meaning to tell you...
(Monica glares triumphantly across the room, scaring Rachel who also stands up.)

utterances.transcript: Would you excuse me for a second?
Remember back in freshman year? Well, Billy Dreskin and I had sex on your bed.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Rachel) Remember back in freshman year? (Talking fast before Rachel can catch her) Well, Billy Dreskin and I had sex on your bed.

(Completely undone by Monica's verbal destruction, Rachel almost loses her balance as she staggers backwards, eyes agog, gasping for breath, and literally not knowing which way to turn. Finally, she escapes into the bathroom while a resigned Dr. Mitchell looks philosophically at Dr. Rosen who seems about remind him of the good old days at the pagan altar.)

utterances.transcript: Hey.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula turns in surprise.)

utterances.transcript: Oh!
Um you, you got a minute?
Um, yeah, I'm just... ..working.
utterances.transcript_with_note: Um, yeah, I'm just... (waving dismissively at the concept) ..working.

(Ursula points out a vacant table, so the twins walk over, side by side, to sit down. Departing customers walk right past the pair. Sitting at the back, a hungry gentleman looks most annoyed as Ursula sets his meal down in front of her. The girls sit.)

utterances.transcript: So.
Uh-huh.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula is genuinely pleased that her sister has visited her, after so many years. Phoebe hesitates over how best to begin.)

utterances.transcript: Um, oh, I got you a birthday present.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula picks up a fork and begins eating the meat, while Phoebe removes a present from her bag.)

utterances.transcript: Oh, wow! You remembered! Oh! It's a Judy Jetson thermos!
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh, wow! You remembered! (Opening it) Oh! It's a Judy Jetson thermos!
(She laughs at the childhood memory. Phoebe smiles at being able to make her point.)

utterances.transcript: Right, like the kind you...
Right... Oh, I got something for you, too.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula gets up to fetch a box from her bag by the counter.)

utterances.transcript: How'd you know I was coming?
Um, yeah, um, twin thing.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula puts the box directly into Phoebe's hand. Phoebe brightens.)

utterances.transcript: I can't believe you did this.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Phoebe opens the box, to find something familiar inside.)

utterances.transcript: I can't believe you... ..did this.
utterances.transcript_with_note: I can't believe you... (holding up Joey's cardigan) ..did this.
(Phoebe's smile hardens as she packs the cardigan away.)

utterances.transcript: So... What's the deal with umm, you and Joey?
Oh, right. He is so great. But that's over.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula resumes eating her lunch..)

utterances.transcript: Does he know?
Who?
Joey. You know, um, he's really nutsy about you.
He is? Why?
You got me.
Right.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (A waiter comes over for the stolen chicken. Ursula turns to him.)

utterances.transcript: Excuse me. Doesn't this come with a side salad?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (The man gives up, shaking his head.)

utterances.transcript: So, um, are you gonna call him?
What? Do you think he likes me?
utterances.transcript_with_note: What? (Indicating the departing waiter) Do you think he likes me?

utterances.transcript: No, Joey.
Oh. No, no, he is so smart. He'll figure it out. Do you want some chicken?
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh. No, no, he is so smart. He'll figure it out. (Offering to share her food) Do you want some chicken?

utterances.transcript: No. No food with a face.
You have not changed!

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Ursula's eyes dance as she laughs and smiles, simply glad to be back with her sister.)

utterances.transcript: Yeah, you too.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Trying not to wrinkle her nose, Phoebe smiles back realising it's down to her to make up for her negligent sister. Meanwhile, Ursula still hasn't received her side salad, but when she attempts to attract the waiter's attention, he ignores her.)

I'm sorry.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) I'm sorry.

utterances.transcript: I don't get it. What happened? What about everything you said under the bridge?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Phoebe is almost thrown by this.)

utterances.transcript: : Yeah, um... You know you, you should just forget about what I said under the bridge, I was talkin' crazy that night, I was so drunk!

utterances.transcript: You don't drink.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) That's right, I don't... But I was, I was drunk on you!

utterances.transcript: Oh, Urse...
utterances.transcript_with_note: Oh, Urse... (He tries to take her in his arms, but she fends him off.)

utterances.transcript: Okay, yeah, so it's not gonna work.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) Okay, yeah, so it's not gonna work.

utterances.transcript: Why? Is it because I'm friends with Phoebe?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) If it was, would you stop hanging out with her?

utterances.transcript: no. No, I, I couldn't do that.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (Thinking carefully) no. No, I, I couldn't do that.

utterances.transcript: Um, then yes, it's 'cause of Phoebe! So, you know, it's either her or me.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) Um, then yes, it's 'cause of Phoebe! So, you know, it's either her or me.

utterances.transcript: Then, uh, then I'm sorry.

utterances.transcript_with_note: (He sinks to the sofa, saddened by Ursula's ultimatum, while Phoebe follows, touched by Joey's good heart.)

utterances.transcript: You know... You're gonna be really, really hard to get over.
utterances.transcript_with_note: (as Ursula) You know... (unconsciously putting a hand on his knee) You're gonna be really, really hard to get over.

utterances.transcript: I know...

utterances.transcript_with_note: (He looks up at her face and Phoebe, slipping out of character, smiles back at him. Joey's voice becomes soft and warm.)

utterances.transcript: I don't know whether it's just 'cause we're breakin' up or... what, but you have never looked so beautiful.
Really?

utterances.transcript_with_note: (Phoebe smiles, when Joey takes her face in his hands and kisses her. Joey gets up to leave but stops suddenly. Phoebe silently shouts "Oh, whoa!!" to herself, and leans back in the sofa to recover, a hand to her tingling lips. A thoughtful Joey is also feeling his lips, so he hesitates for a moment, then returns for a better view, he thinks again, cocking his head from side to side to regard her profile from various angles, then...)
